value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">angular, gigantic; freed from something impure; yet</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">old; sin tarnishedl corruptL in the middle of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the fresh, innocent landscape, remembering;–</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>par</del> <del>It</del> To follow the Knights & ladies in this</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">strange pre-historic England is to lose our 
            <choice>
              <sic>beags</sic>
              <corr>bearings</corr>
            </choice>; to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">shed many habits of thoughtl but <del>we</del> after all</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>this</del> it is not an imprinted fabricated world; it is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">behind us still, deep down; <del>&</del> savage, primitive, still</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>existing</del> ending</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>But</del> Of the writer, nothing is known.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He does not exist apart from his book. It is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>like</del> the anonymous voice speaking</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">anonymously; the voice of a very old yet <del>still</del> still</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">common world, where the story is already known to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the listener, <del>where the listener</del> the listener</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the voice of an unknown man, who has been</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">travelling in strange parts, & comes to the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">door, across the marsh, through the flood,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to remind the noble & the peasant of what</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he has heard long ago.</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
          <l>XVII</l>
        </add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">In the great house & in the cottage this half articulate</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">anonymous voice murmured of old Gods, & Kings, & Knights</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">& Ladies. The well & the tree were still</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">haunted. <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#kart" key="Arthur (King)">King arthur</rs> the traveller tell</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add place="margin">XVII</add> that <quote source="#" place="inline">about noon, or about midnight, when the</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" place="inline">moon is full & shining, they often see an assay of</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" place="inline">hawkers with dogs & sound of horses, who, in</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" place="inline">answer to the [enquiries?] say that they are</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" place="inline">of the [homestead?] & fellowship of Arthur."</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Along the roads from town to town, from one</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great house to another came the [mummers?] & the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">rhymers, the jugglers the bear leaders, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">speakers of ballads, <del>the fo</del> while for these</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">who could read it & hear it, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wcax" key="Caxton, William">Caxton</rs></l>
